8.44.text:
Jeff, thank you very much for
your time today.

11.66.text: >> Yeah, it's great to be here.

13.21.text:
>> Let me start off by saying that we
usually ease in to those conversations

20.28.text:
there is a very special topic
in everyone's mind this week.

24.39.text: And that is recent immigration policies.

26.93.text:
So, we are 40% international and
it's affected us quite deeply.

34.52.text:
So as a CEO representing
your company to the public,

37.54.text:
how did you think about reacting
to last weekend's executive order?

42.97.text:
>> Yeah, first of all, it's great to be
here, thank you so much for having me.

47.24.text:
>> So there's different ways to go
about addressing an issue like that,

52.27.text:
and you have to think about,
your audience, your constituencies and

57.30.text:
who you're trying to reach and
what your objectives are.

61.50.text:
The first thing to keep in mind in
a situation like that, at least for

65.95.text:
us at LinkedIn, is the well being and
the safety of our employees.

71.40.text:
We, like the student body here, have
a number of immigrants at the company.

78.26.text: We have a number of people who have yet

80.11.text:
to become citizens who are here
on working visas and green cards.

85.11.text:
And we want to make sure that
we could identify anyone

89.25.text:
who was a citizen from one of
the named seven countries.

93.13.text:
And that they were here and
present and accounted for and safe.

97.82.text:
And we want to also do that for
their immediate family.

102.63.text: So that was the very first consideration.

105.82.text:
The next thing we wanted to do
was make sure that we were making

112.01.text:
clear how people could get involved if
they wanted to help and make a difference.

118.49.text:
As a company, our vision is to
create economic opportunity for

122.42.text:
every member of the global workforce,
all of them.

125.63.text:
That is irrespective of country of origin,
ethnicity, religious belief.

131.42.text:
And we have had some
ongoing programmes to help

136.45.text:
refugees find work that started in
Sweden and we had some success there.

141.69.text:
So [INAUDIBLE] success we extended
that programme to Canada.

144.68.text:
And with the executive order that was
announced here last Friday, we accelerated

148.55.text:
the launch of, what we call the welcome
talent program here in the United States.

152.99.text:
We also wanted to make sure that
employees who wanted to get involved,

155.80.text:
understood that through our employee-based
foundation, they could contribute and

161.44.text:
we could allocate those funds to
efforts that are making a difference.

167.27.text:
Then there was the third kind of
dimension of this which is making clear,

174.46.text:
at least from my perspective, where I
stood on this and it's important, I don't

180.45.text:
feel the need to comment on everything,
to be able to comment on anything.

185.60.text:
And from time to time there are going to
be issues that I feel are important for

191.12.text:
me to address, and
they're important to our employees.

195.31.text: And this is one of those times.

197.44.text:
And in a situation like this,
least to my experience,

202.63.text:
one of the things that I've
learned is that you have to strike

207.82.text:
a very delicate balance when you're
expressing personal belief vs

212.51.text:
expressing belief as a CEO, because you're
representing your employees, your company.

217.70.text:
And in this particular instance, I felt
the need to express my own views on this.

223.43.text:
And that was that this country,
the United States, was founded

229.33.text:
on our first principle and
belief that all people

234.65.text:
should have an inalienable right to life,
liberty and the pursuit of happiness.

243.79.text: >> That America has truly been a land of

249.57.text:
It is a country and an economy that was
largely built on the tireless efforts

255.18.text:
of immigrants who came to this country
seeking a better life for themselves and

258.64.text:
their families, that ultimately
created a spirit of entrepreneurship.

264.01.text:
And were able to innovate and
introduced products and services and

267.32.text:
build companies that employed many,
many people and

270.62.text:
made a difference in a lives of so
many in this country and beyond.

274.50.text:
And I shared through social media
the statistic that some people maybe less

279.46.text:
familiar with but that 40% of the Fortune
500 was founded by immigrants or

284.74.text:
the children of immigrants just as one
empirical point to support this idea.

289.88.text:
And then again coming back to our
vision as a company where this becomes

294.47.text:
aligned is our position, our purpose
to create economic opportunity for

299.28.text: every member of the global workforce.

301.86.text:
And so I was expressing that position and
at the same time, and

305.52.text:
you asked the question, how is the CEO do
I address this, it's very important for

310.37.text:
any of you that go on to start
your own company, join companies,

314.17.text:
become senior leadership or become a CEO
yourself, that you recognize that not

318.88.text:
every employee within your
organization may agree with you or

322.54.text:
may agree with the people they
work next to day in and day out.

326.17.text: And this was a very valuable lesson

329.33.text:
that many of us learned
during this election cycle.

Because a lot of folks in California

338.10.text:
vote a certain way, within a specific

And so, as I was expressing these
thoughts, I wanted to make sure that our

347.94.text:

that other people within the organization

353.26.text:
may disagree, and that we should be
respectful of those disagreements.

358.77.text:
We want to create an environment
where people feel like they belong

362.01.text:
as long as that's consistent
with our culture and values.

365.65.text:
And again, that is an organization and
an environment where all people,

370.46.text:
irrespective of their country of origin,
their political leanings or affiliations,

376.49.text:
their creeds, their orientation,
it is independent of all those things.

381.94.text:
We're going to treat one another with
compassion and we're going to take care of

384.70.text:
one another, we're going to
be respectful of one another.

387.28.text: >> Thank you very much for that.

388.12.text:
We've been having a very rich debate over
the past few days internally between both

393.59.text:
drawing the line between our personal
reactions to what as an institution

397.35.text:
we need to represent, has been a tricky,
I'll say at least, discussion.

402.96.text:
So thank you very much for
this perspective, it's great.

405.83.text:
And before we go into the specifics of
LinkedIn, I wanted to get your take on

409.66.text:
another topic that could potentially
have very high impact on the workforce.

413.91.text:
So a couple of months ago you
addressed the LinkedIn employees and

418.17.text:
you told them about what some people refer
to as the fourth industrial revolution.

423.14.text:
So can you tell us a bit more about that
concept and how you think it's actually

426.29.text:
going to shift the dynamics of
the workforce and the economy as well?

429.10.text:
>> Yeah, absolutely, so
this was a theory that

434.34.text:
I first became familiar with
through the World Economic Forum,

438.20.text:
they were talking about
the fourth industrial revolution.

441.55.text:
The first, mechanization,
largely based on the steam engine.

446.74.text:
And the second was mass production,
and that was largely based on

452.10.text:
the introduction of electricity, division
of labor, assembly lines and factories.

457.92.text:
The third was automation and that followed
electronics, early stage computing and IT.

464.97.text:
And this fourth industrial
revolution based on robotization.

472.98.text:
the innovations underpinning this fourth
industrial revolution includes robots.

483.21.text:
And what's noteworthy about this
Fourth Industrial Revolution is that,

488.49.text:
in the first three cases, new innovations,
new technologies gave rise to

493.77.text:
companies that generated massive gains in
productivity and new job opportunities.

500.62.text:
And there is increasingly
a belief that in this

503.49.text:
latest Fourth Industrial Revolution
that may not be the case.

507.40.text:
That the new technologies may
actually displace more workers and

513.71.text:
that was the case in this body of research
from the World Economic Forum, where

517.79.text:
they predicted, well, 7 million gross jobs
would be eliminated between now and 2020.

522.70.text:
2 million would be added through
the advent of new technologies,

526.50.text: so we would lose 5 million jobs.

528.40.text:
And there are some that believe that
is a highly conservative estimate.

531.64.text:
That more people than that will
be displaced as a result of new

534.83.text:
technologies and innovation and
you can see this now and start to feel it.

538.72.text:
And sure enough, at this year's
Davos event that's hosted by

542.34.text:
the World Economic Forum, there was
a general consensus that one of the key

546.64.text:
points to come out of this one,
the key learnings was this whole meme,

550.67.text:
this whole idea,
has been discussed now for years.

555.20.text:
And if you talked to attendees this year,
they felt like something had tipped.

559.57.text:
And whether it was heads of state or
CEOs, founders,

563.17.text:
there was a general consensus that
it was no longer a prognostication.

569.66.text:
And all of you have probably seen
this anecdotally, week in and

573.32.text:
week out,
if you're following business news.

576.62.text: It seems like literally every other week,

579.41.text:
there's another story about a major

584.07.text:
robot technology that will displace
tens of thousands of people.

588.43.text:
Or a major retailer and
major warehousing infrastructure that has

593.09.text:
grown the number of robots being
deployed by tens of thousands.

597.59.text:
Or autonomous driving which has the
potential to happen far faster than anyone

603.90.text: And for those that don't know,

605.18.text:
trucking, it's the number one
profession in California.

608.71.text: A lot of people don't realize that.

610.73.text: And what happens to those folks?

613.71.text:
I think it's absolutely essential
that any time there are stories about

620.56.text:
these new technologies, it's wonderful
to be excited about innovation and

625.48.text:
things that could potentially unlock tons
of value on a global basis for people.

630.09.text:
But I think it's also equally important,
if not more important,

632.96.text:
every time we see these articles to

637.24.text:
who are being impacted and
potentially displaced.

640.45.text:
What programs are we putting into
place to reskill these employees?

644.88.text:
Are they being certified in new skills for
the jobs that are and

648.42.text:
will be as opposed to
the jobs that once were?

Where is the spirit of
entrepreneurship and

654.40.text:
the investment and
the energy in vocational training and

658.81.text:
innovation in how we train people to
take on these new technologies and

664.22.text:
the job opportunities created
by these new technologies?

668.83.text:
How are we leveraging infrastructure
that we couldn't have even dreamed of

674.60.text:
Take LinkedIn as an example,
when you look at the data we have,

677.34.text:
we're developing the world's
first economic graph and

679.83.text:
our understanding take any
locality in the world.

682.07.text:
And we're in a position now where we can
understand the fastest growing jobs within

685.77.text:
that locality,
the skills required to obtain those jobs.

688.43.text:
We can understand the skills of the

692.19.text:
We can measure the gap and then we can
provide this data to junior colleges,

696.42.text:
vocational training facilities,
even four year universities and

700.25.text:
help them to create just
in time curriculum.

702.82.text:
This is the kind of thing, I think,
increasingly as a society,

706.46.text:
we need to be spending more time
on understanding and solving for.

710.25.text:
>> All right, so actually you've touched

which is educational reform is something

So let me rephrase the question and ask

I think from a generational

742.84.text:
And we need to make sure that
increasingly, we are providing schools and

748.45.text:

the technology they need

753.51.text:
to bring our students into
the 21st century successfully.

758.31.text:
Rote learning and the same things that

763.43.text:
the industrial revolutions that

For those who don't know, well,

786.69.text:
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay, do you know why in part,

we sit in rows and
why rote learning was such

794.79.text:
an important part of primary school,

803.51.text: we exist in a different world and

805.42.text:
increasingly the world has become

Things change much faster

813.55.text:
And so,
we need to teach critical reasoning.

I think there are now technologies

835.82.text:
that will help teachers and

more of their time on

And we can leverage adaptive

850.64.text:
And we're still in very early innings in

We were talking a little bit about

moving beyond the generational change,

we gotta start investing

867.50.text:
But what about the workers

870.02.text:
We need to go all in on

874.14.text:
And historically, and speaking of in

879.68.text:
I think,
we've placed tremendous emphasis and

883.13.text:
weighting on degrees from prestigious four

But it's also important for

path to have access to an education,
where they can develop a skill and

903.16.text:
a trade that they can utilize to earn

908.93.text:
And you see this in countries like Germany

915.46.text:
And so this isn't just a technical issue,

922.42.text: >> Thank you very much for that.

Now, we want to get to know

we're going to take you a little bit back

>> I thought we were about to do,

they start flashing

>> Reid Hoffman,

>> I had him in a class

Good man, very, very bright,

and that's actually a part of why

So I first met Reid,

We were at a restaurant in San Francisco

983.77.text:
an event we titled Brainstorm and

987.44.text:
30 folks from the Valley about their

992.61.text:
And I remember Reid answering
a question that's been posed, and

995.47.text:
I was really struck by not
only his intelligence but

999.38.text:
how he was coming at it from
a different perspective.

1001.33.text:
And we have been told by different people
who knew us that we should meet at some

1006.67.text:
So we had a chance to
meet on that occasion.

1009.34.text:
And little piece of trivia,
Reid was actually the last guest speaker I

1013.86.text:
brought in to talk to my team
when I was an executive at Yahoo,

1017.76.text: before I ended up leaving the company.

1020.51.text:
At any rate, when LinkedIn elected
to make a change at the CEO level,

1026.72.text:
for those that don't know,
Reid had been the founder and CEO.

1030.14.text:
He had then hired a professional CEO, a
guy named Dan Nye who did a wonderful job.

1035.47.text:
And Reid was the president of product,
reporting to Dan who was the CEO,

1041.17.text:
who then reported to Reid as
the chairman and founder of the company.

1052.58.text:
it didn't work out
the way people had hoped.

1056.86.text:
And the two of them had a great
deal of admiration for one another.

1059.45.text: That's not what it was about.

1060.53.text:
So when Reid was looking to make a change
and he asked me to get involved, he said,

1065.46.text:
I was at the time, I was an executive
in residency at Greylock, and

1071.72.text:
And I understood they were making
a change and someone said,

1073.50.text: would I be interested in helping out?

1075.37.text: That's one of the reasons I'm here.

1077.18.text:
So I'll take a couple of days a week and
I'll help Reid out in any way I can.

1080.50.text:
And he said, okay,
you should go meet with him.

1084.10.text: So I go and meet with Reid.

1085.32.text: We were actually in his house.

1087.07.text:
And I think I was sitting in a LinkedIn
bean bag chair with the words innovation,

1092.72.text: and everything had an In logo on it.

1095.28.text: And he said, so I have two lists.

1097.85.text:
I have an interim CEO list and
a full time CEO list, and

1101.40.text: you're the only person on both lists.

1105.56.text: I was going to volunteer to help.

1107.81.text:
He's like, no, no, you gotta come in and
let's make this happen.

1112.41.text:
So I agreed that I was going to
start on an interim basis

1117.12.text: because I had just left Yahoo.

1119.86.text: I was there for a number of years, and

1121.72.text:
I wasn't sure how quickly I wanted to
get back into a full time position.

1125.86.text:
And I said as long as he was
open to having me full time and

1127.81.text:
I could start interim,
I'd be open to that.

1129.28.text:
And he said as often as you're
open to being full time,

1131.19.text:
you'll start as interim and
then we'll see how it goes.

1134.37.text: The night before I joined, I called him.

1136.24.text:
I was going to start as interim president
with all the responsibilities of a CEO,

1141.10.text:
said so, you're still going to be the CEO,
at least in title symbolically.

1145.51.text: I'm coming in as interim president.

1146.70.text: Which decisions would you like to make and

1148.68.text:
which decisions do you think
I should be responsible for?

1150.91.text:
I want to make sure we had
clarity before I started.

1155.15.text: It's your ball, you run with it.

1159.94.text:
He said, yeah,
you're going to make all the decisions.

1162.90.text:
That's why I'm bringing you in like this,
and I just learned what not to do.

1168.06.text:
Now to give you an indication of truly how
thoughtful he is, he went a step further.

1174.45.text:
And over the course of the first
ten weeks I was at LinkedIn,

1177.66.text:
Reid was out of the office,
he scheduled trips and travel, for

1181.53.text: roughly six to eight weeks of that time.

1184.02.text:
Because he recognized, no matter what we
explained to people, that muscle memory

1189.39.text:
was still going to be in place and
people were still going to go to him.

1193.40.text:
So he literally physically took
himself out of the situation so

1196.86.text:
I could build that connective
tissue with the organization.

1201.25.text:
So between that and between
the graciousness of my predecessor,

1206.02.text: Dan Nein, the way he handed off the baton.

1210.56.text:
the person who's leaving the company
can sometimes be angry and bitter.

1215.66.text:
And they can poison
the well to some extent.

1217.76.text: And Dan did the exact opposite.

1220.47.text:
He operated with absolute integrity
throughout the entire process.

1224.03.text:
The last thing I would say is one of
the most frequently asked questions I

1228.54.text:
got when I first joined LinkedIn was,
what's it like working with Reid?

1232.69.text:
And that was code for what's all
the drama happening between you and

1238.85.text:
And what people didn't realize
was I joined LinkedIn,

1242.67.text:
not in spite of Reid, but
in large part because of Reid.

1246.51.text:
I had a tremendous amount of respect and

And he's gone on to become
one of my closest friends,

1255.23.text:
someone I would certainly go to for

1257.65.text:
And we've had a wonderful
partnership ever since.

1261.42.text: >> Well, you've built a great thing.

>> And
you stress on purpose-driven culture.

how did that translate to the culture
that you guys built over there?

1271.70.text:
>> Yeah, so I mentioned earlier our

1276.05.text: every member of the global workforce.

We separate vision and
mission at LinkedIn.

1282.03.text:
Some companies use these synonymously,

1286.00.text: Vision for us is the dream.

1287.63.text:
It gets us out of bed every morning,

1292.16.text: Mission is an overarching objective for

1295.07.text:
the organization that is realizable,

1303.62.text:
Our mission is to connect the world's

1309.56.text: We believe deeply in our mission.

1311.44.text: We believe deeply in our vision.

1313.36.text:
And our sense of purpose is one of the
things that defines us as an organization.

1319.24.text: It's not just the what, however.

1321.86.text: It's also the how, our culture and values.

1324.37.text:
It's not just about what were
trying to accomplish and

1328.17.text: It's how we go about doing that.

1330.60.text:
And increasingly, I think both purpose and
the idea of culture and

1335.32.text:
values is what attracts
people to join organizations.

1339.36.text:
That's certainly the case with the younger

1342.92.text:
generation, where you find time and

1347.98.text:
by purpose than they do some of the things

1355.09.text:
Compensation, title,
these things are still important.

1358.22.text:
But I think talking to more and
more younger people,

1360.68.text:
purpose and what the company is ultimately
trying to accomplish, and the impact

1364.49.text:
it's going to have in the world,
that seems to be more heavily weighted.

1367.87.text: And it's not just among employees.

1370.14.text:
It's also increasingly customers who,
by virtue of social media,

who did an amazing job,

>> Yeah, I have seen that interview,

2717.16.text:

how many of you watch Super Soul Sunday,

>> [LAUGH]
>> Will didn't even, thank you, Will.

2734.60.text:

2741.28.text:
And she said, in reading one

2747.14.text:
I had been known in a prior role before

2753.36.text:
[LAUGH] Which I think would be
putting it somewhat euphemistically.

2757.48.text: And I am intense and I was intense.

2760.63.text:
We talked a little bit about my management

2764.80.text:

2767.98.text:
And it's not like yelling and

2771.54.text:
Different management style
though when I have to.

2781.33.text:
And I told her about some specific things
that had occurred within my role at

2787.57.text:
But at the end of the day,

2790.23.text: me personally was meeting my wife.

2792.68.text:
>> And my wife led to a very
different perspective for me.

2799.49.text:
And she valued things that I hadn't

2805.28.text: Things like kindness, and love, and

gratitude, and
it changed everything for me.

2816.21.text:
And I'm very,
very fortunate to have met here.

2818.81.text: And you hear all the time,

2820.67.text:
I wouldn't be in this position

2828.72.text: >> Thank you very much for that.

>> Jeff, thanks for being here and

I want to go back to where

And as you think about as an executive and
as a visible person in the valley,

2857.89.text:
how do you think about which topics
to speak on and which not to?

we've seen a lot of execs talk about

2865.82.text:
the Executive orders and yet
these weeks starts Black History month and

2870.25.text:
that hasn't gotten an equal amount of
attention, how do you think about which

2874.29.text:
topics to show up on and which not to and

2878.17.text:
>> Yeah, so interestingly enough
we have a lot of activity

2882.46.text:
plan within LinkedIn on
Black History month.

2886.03.text:
And it's been led by an amazing employee,
resource group and

2890.35.text:
our leadership there and
we're excited about that.

2895.26.text: You asked an excellent question and

2899.37.text:
my first response would be
there is no formula for this.

2903.80.text: There's no cookie cutter approach to this.

2907.77.text:
It, at times, is a deeply personal
decision, I think it's really important

2913.65.text:
to know where you stand, if you're
going to be in a position of leadership.

2919.18.text:
To know what your company
is trying to accomplish,

2922.40.text: to know how it wants to accomplish it,

2924.80.text:
to be very clear with people about
those values and where you draw lines.

2929.38.text:
And where you're willing to compromise and
where you're not.

2934.16.text:
And when those lines get crossed,
to do something about it,

2938.54.text: to speak up, to take action.

2941.81.text:
And at the same time to recognize
that your personal beliefs maybe at

2947.34.text:
odds with the personal beliefs of people
that worked within your organization.

2953.94.text:
And that as long as people who disagree
do so in a mutually respectful and

2960.01.text:
compassionate and
constructive way that is consistent

2964.78.text:
with the way in which you want
to go about your business.

2970.36.text:
Consistent with your culture and
consistent with your values, that every

2974.71.text:
individual within an organisation
should feel as if they belong there.

2978.93.text:
So that's the approach that I've taken,
that we take as a leadership team.

2982.99.text:
But it's going to be different depending
on who you're talking to, depending

2986.24.text:
on what they're trying to accomplish,
depending on their own experiences.

of rolling out a new version of

3062.86.text:

the assets that we've been able to

3067.53.text:
One of the things that we're

3075.35.text:

3080.15.text:
Microsoft has invested
very heavily in this area.

3082.81.text:
And we can bring that to bear
on LinkedIn through things like

3086.69.text:
a bot experience that you could think

3095.29.text:

calendar integration and

3098.14.text:
providing you the information you
need to be better prepared for

3100.79.text: the person you're about to meet.

Or ultimately making sure you have access
to the right information to complete

3108.26.text:
There's a whole host of things that we're

3111.85.text:
We're going to continue to invest very
aggressively in making our feed and

3115.70.text:
the content within out feed more
relevant and more personally relevant.

3120.31.text:
We've only begun to scratch
the surface there, and

3122.34.text:
what you're going to start to see this

3125.27.text:
So we can take packages of content
by virtue of machine learning,

3129.18.text:
social queues, and our editorial team and

3133.78.text:
So whether it's around the executive order
or a major announcement by your company,

3140.02.text:
or a shift in the economy, you can not

3145.13.text:
by publishers that you're following, or

3149.41.text:
what people in your network are saying,
and

3151.31.text:
the information you need to know right now

3155.33.text:
So we've only begin to scratch the surface

3159.86.text:
We are going to be starting to think
about, how and this is somewhat consistent

3165.37.text:
with second part of your question,

3170.63.text:

Not just jobs per se, although that's a

3203.09.text:
marketplace dynamics,
so stay tuned for that.

3205.83.text:
We're going to start to

And that's largely [INAUDIBLE] from

notifications within Windows,

3255.21.text:
In terms of advice, I would give to you if
you're interested in starting a company,

3261.31.text:
I guess it wouldn't be to similar from the
advice I would give anyone in the audience

3265.38.text:
in terms of how to optimize for their
career path and how to achieve success.

3272.36.text:
And that would be first and foremost take
the time to understand what it is you're

3277.66.text:
And the more specific you can be,
the more likely you will be to achieve it,

3282.56.text:
and you're going to manifest that
in ways explicit and implicit.

3286.77.text:
And I don't mean this in some
new agey predeterministic way,

3292.36.text:
The clearer you are about what it
is that you want to accomplish,

3295.99.text:
the more you can clearly communicate
that to the people around you.

3299.72.text: The more doors are going to open up,

3301.06.text:
the more you're going to attract
the right kind of opportunities.

3305.29.text: And when it comes to defining what it is,

3307.43.text:
you ought to know what you want to
accomplish, try to optimize for

3310.83.text:
two things, your passion and your skill,
not one at the exclusion of the other.

3316.45.text:
Second, would be to surround yourself with
the best possible talent that you can.

3321.97.text:
And when I was younger, I used to think
that was all about itching my wagon's

3326.53.text:
the right train in terms of my boss or
mentor.

3329.24.text:
And as I gotten older, I've realized
that is the world becomes more network,

3334.47.text:
as we become more dependent on knowledge,
having the right knowledge at

3339.30.text:
the right time to accomplish certain
objectives, it's really about people.

3344.63.text:
And so it's not just about who you
work for, it's about who you work

3349.53.text:
alongside of and who works for you and
making sure that you don't settle and

3354.96.text:
you don't compromise, in terms of
where you set that bar on skill and

3359.95.text: talent and on fit with your own values.

3365.82.text:
Personally, I like to work with people
who dream big, who, can we curse here,

3371.22.text:
is that all right, okay, who get shit done
[LAUGH] and who know how to have fun.

3376.48.text:
Not to be confused with constantly
partying because it's going to be

3379.19.text:
difficult to get work done if
you're constantly partying.

3382.05.text:
But knowing how to have fun as a proxy for
being of like minds culturally.

3386.65.text:
So surround yourself with
only the best talent.

3388.60.text:
And the third would be
to always be learning.

3391.94.text: The world is changing so fast right now.

3395.46.text:
There's an acceleration, it's like log or
rhythmic, the rate of innovation.

3399.70.text:
And the days where you could study
one thing and have a role or

3403.57.text:
a job guaranteed for the rest of your
life, I think those days are long gone.

3408.53.text:
We have to constantly be learning,
continuously learning.

3412.24.text:
And if you have a natural inclination or
passion for that,

3417.51.text:
if you're naturally curious
about the world around you,

3422.79.text:
you will be that much better positioned
to continue to learn over time.

3429.26.text:
>> We're not Oprah's soul Sundays but
